facts.fact: Ohrid was known as Lychnidos in ancient times, meaning 'City of Light' in ancient Greek, due to the white limestone cliffs reflecting sunlight across the lake.
The Ancient Theatre of Ohrid, built around 200 BC, could hold up to 5,000 spectators and is still used today for concerts and festivals.
Saint Clement of Ohrid established the first Slavic university here in 893 AD, making it the cradle of Slavic literacy and culture.
The Cyrillic alphabet was perfected in Ohrid by Saint Clement
Samuel's Fortress, built in the 10th century, offers one of the most spectacular views of Lake Ohrid.
The Church of Saint Sophia contains frescoes from the 11th century, representing some of the finest examples of Byzantine art in the Balkans.
Ohrid has exactly 365 churches - one for each day of the year - earning it the nickname 'Jerusalem of the Balkans'.
The Church of Saint John at Kaneo, perched dramatically on a cliff, is Ohrid's most photographed landmark and dates to the 13th century.
Lake Ohrid is one of Europe's oldest lakes, estimated to be 2-3 million years old, hosting over 200 endemic species.
The famous Ohrid trout (Salmo letnica) is endemic to Lake Ohrid and has been a local delicacy for over 2,000 years.
UNESCO declared both Lake Ohrid and the city as World Heritage Sites - one of the few places with dual natural and cultural recognition.
The traditional Ohrid houses with their wooden balconies and Ottoman-era architecture showcase 500 years of cultural fusion.
The Via Egnatia, the ancient Roman road connecting Rome to Constantinople, passed through Lychnidos (Ohrid), making it a major trade hub.
Saint Naum Monastery, 29km from Ohrid, was built by Saint Naum of Preslav in 905 AD and houses peacocks that roam freely in its gardens.
The Robevci House, now a museum, showcases traditional 19th-century Ohrid lifestyle with authentic furniture and ethnographic artifacts.
Ohrid's Old Bazaar has been a center of trade and craftsmanship for over 500 years, still featuring traditional Macedonian handicrafts.
The Ohrid Summer Festival, established in 1961, transforms ancient venues into world-class performance spaces every July and August.
Lake Ohrid reaches a maximum depth of 288 meters, making it one of the deepest lakes in the Balkans.
The Plaošnik archaeological site revealed remains of Saint Clement's original monastery and the first Slavic university in the world.
Ohrid pearls, made from fish scales of the endemic Ohrid bleak fish, were a luxury item traded throughout Europe for centuries.
The city survived invasions by Romans, Byzantines, Bulgarians, Serbs, and Ottomans, each leaving their architectural and cultural mark.
Traditional Ohrid boats called 'čun' have been used for fishing on the lake for over 1,000 years, with designs unchanged since medieval times.
The Monastery of Saint Panteleimon contains the tomb of Saint Clement and is considered one of the most sacred sites in Orthodox Christianity.
Ohrid's city walls once extended all the way to the lake shore, with underwater foundations still visible in clear weather.
During WWII, Ohrid served as a safe haven for refugees and resistance fighters, with many hidden passages and secret rooms still existing today.
The traditional Ohrid song 'Lihnida Kajche Vslashe' is one of North Macedonia's most beloved folk songs.
The word 'Ohrid' comes from the Slavic 'оh rid', meaning 'on the hill', referring to the city's elevated position above the lake.
